title: EPSY 5221 Assignments
text:
Course: EPSY 5221 - Principles of Educational and Psychological Measurement
Semester: Spring 2025, 3 credits
Instructor: Nana Kim, Ph.D.

Department: Quantitative Methods in Education (QME), Educational Psychology
Office: 165 Education Sciences Building
Email: nkim530@umn.edu




This course is an introductory course to educational and psychological measurement. Measuring constructs such as knowledge, personality, and attitudes is fundamental to research and practice in education, psychology, and social sciences. This course aims to help students develop knowledge and skills to develop, evaluate, and use tests/measurement instruments. The course introduces principles and practices of measurement methods in educational and psychological settings. Test theories such as classical test theory (CTT) and item response theory (IRT) will be considered and fundamental concepts such as reliability, validity, and fairness will be discussed.




Assignment 01 - Due February 20, 2025
Assignment 02 - Coming soon




This website contains my assignments for EPSY 5221. All course materials and designs are property of Professor Nana Kim. For any citation or reference of these materials, please contact Professor Nana Kim directly at nkim530@umn.edu.

Last updated: February 2025

title: Assignment-01
text:
A performance test of manual dexterity was administered to a group of subjects. The frequency distribution is reported as follows.



Score
50
60
70
80
90




Frequency
1
2
3
3
1







Compute the mean, variance, and standard deviation of the score distribution.
Hint: You can use mean(), var(), and sd() functions in R.





Code
# Create the data
scores <- rep(c(50, 60, 70, 80, 90), times=c(1, 2, 3, 3, 1))

# Calculate statistics
mean(scores)


[1] 71


Code
var(scores)


[1] 143.3333


Code
sd(scores)


[1] 11.97219


Code
sd(scores)/sqrt(length(scores))


[1] 3.785939


Code
## Values of the answer below is calculated by function round(), e.g.: round(sd(scores),2)








Report




The mean of this score distribution is 71
The variance of the score distribution is 143.33
The standard deviation of the score distribution is 11.97









The following table contains raw scores, z-scores, and T-scores for Joan and Peter from the group. Complete the table by finding out the unknown values (a), (b), and (c).



Name
Raw score
z-score
T-score




Joan
80.00
0.75
57.50


Peter
49.45
-1.80
32.00












Solution Process



According to Part 1, \(\mu\) estimated by the distribution is 71 and \(\sigma\) is 11.97.




\[
\begin{aligned}
z &= \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \\
z &= \frac{80 - 71}{11.97} = \frac{9}{11.97} \approx 0.75
\end{aligned}
\]



\[
X = z \cdot \sigma + \mu
\]
Substituting the values for Peter’s z-score:
\[
\begin{aligned}
X &= (-1.80) \cdot 11.97 + 71 \\
X &= -21.53 + 71 = 49.47
\end{aligned}
\]



The formula of T score is : \[
T = 10\cdot z+50
\] Calculate the Joan’s T score by z-score \[
T = 10\cdot(-1.80)+50=32
\]

title: Assignment-01
text:
2 Question 2 [11pts]
James is interested in finding the relationship between Introversion and Social Dominance. He collected the following data and calculated the descriptive statistics of the data.
















Examinee
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
Mean
SD




Introversion
0
1
1
2
2
3
4
5
2.25
1.67


Social Dominance
4
5
4
2
3
3
2
1
3.00
1.31




2.1 Part 1 [3pts]

2.1.1 Question
Obtain a scatter plot of the two variables by using plot() function in R. Please put Introversion on the x-axis and Social Dominance on the y-axis.
Hint: You can construct the dataset in .csv or .txt format and import the data OR you can also create data objects by running the codes below:


2.1.2 Answer


Code
Introv <- c(0, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5) 
Socialdom <- c(4, 5, 4, 2, 3, 3, 2, 1)
#df <- data.frame(Introv, Socialdom)

plot(Introv,Socialdom,main = "Scatter Plot of Introversion and Social Dominance",
     xlab = "Introversion", ylab = "Social Dominance")








Figure 1








2.2 Part 2 [6pts]

2.2.1 Question
Based on the scatter plot you obtained in 2-1), how would you describe the: i) trend ii) strength iii) direction of the association between the two variables? Select your response from the following options for each element:

Positive b) Negative
Linear d) Non-linear
Strong f) Weak



2.2.2 Answer

direction: b) Negative
strength: e) Strong
trend: c) Linear







Details




Direction (Negative): As Introversion increases, Social Dominance tends to decrease.
Strength (Strong): The points are closely clustered around a downward trend, indicating a strong relationship (also can be supported by the correlation coefficient below).
Trend (Linear): The pattern follows a straight line rather than a curve.






2.3 Part 3 [2pts]

2.3.1 Question
Compute the Pearson correlation coefficient between Introversion and Social Dominance using cor() function in R.


2.3.2 Answer


Code
cor(Introv,Socialdom)


[1] -0.8498366


The Pearson correlation between Introversion and Social Dominance is -0.85

title: Assignment-01
text:
3 Question 3 [8pts]
Determine the scale of measurement for each of the following variables.

[2pts] Ranking of baseball teams (determined by their won-lost records at the end of the season): Ordinal Scale
[2pts] Social Security numbers: Nominal Scale
[2pts] Air distance between New York City and other cities in the United States: Interval Scale
[2pts] pH value: Ratio Scale

title: Assignment-01
text:
4 Question 4 [9pts]
The scores of a reference population on the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC) are normally distributed with μ = 100 and σ = 15.

4.0.1 Question 1 [3pts]
Approximately what percentage of the population would score below 100 on the test? 50%


4.0.2 Answer 1






Solution



The WISC scores follow a normal distribution:
\[X \sim \mathcal{N}(100, 15^2)
\]
Here we want to estimate \[
    P(X < 100)
\] Because \(\mu\)=100, so z-score of 100 is 0.
From the standard normal table, the probability of a z-score being less than 0 is 50%


Or directly calculate using R


Code
    pnorm(100, mean = 100, sd = 15)


[1] 0.5




4.0.3 Question 2 [3pts]
Approximately what percentage of the population would score above 130 on the test?


4.0.4 Answer 2
The z score of 130 in this test is 2, so there will be approximately 2.5% of the population would score above 130 on the test.






Solution



Here we want to estimate: \[
    P(X > 130)
\]
Then, calculate the z-score for 130:
\[
    \begin{aligned}
    z &= \frac{130 - 100}{15} \\[1em]
    z &= \frac{30}{15} = 2
    \end{aligned}
\] Based on the standard norm table:
\[
    P(Z > 2) = 1 - P(Z < 2) \approx 1-0.975 \approx 0.025
\]
For z = 2:

Area above z = 2 ≈ 2.5%
Therefore, approximately 2.5% of the population would score above 130



Or directly calculate using R


Code
    1-pnorm(130,mean=100,sd=15)


[1] 0.02275013


Code
    #or
    pnorm(130,mean=100,sd=15,lower.tail = FALSE)


[1] 0.02275013




4.0.5 Question 3 [3pts]
Approximately what percentage of the population would score between 100 and 130 on the test? 47.5%


4.0.6 Answer 3






Solution



Here we want to calculate: \[
    P(100<X<130)
\] From 2 subquestions above,
\[
\begin{aligned}
    P(X < 130) &\approx 0.975\\
    P(X > 100)&=0.5
\end{aligned}
\] So:
\[
P(100<X<130)=P(X < 130)-P(X > 100)=0.975-0.5=47.5%
\]


In R:


Code
    pnorm(130, mean = 100, sd = 15) - pnorm(100, mean = 100, sd = 15)


[1] 0.4772499










Figure 2
